physio-cns.title: Central Nervous System
physio-cns.paragraph: Story of brain and spinal cord
physio-cns.subparagraph: Swipe left or tap on right to start

physio-cns.title: Sensory Nervous System
physio-cns.paragraph:
### Spinal Cord

Central Gray Matter (H shaped) 
 - Have two horns 
 - Dorsal (back side) which are sensory in nature like touch/pain) Sensory, carry sensory neurons into the dorsal horns.
 - Ventrol Horns (front side), They are motor in nature, since they are for muscle contraction using neurons aka eefrants/motor neuorns coming out from ventrol roots aka motor horns.

A pathalogy example would be
 - Polio: Poliovirus damages ventral horns.
 - Result: Motor paralysis (patient cannot move due to loss of motor neurons).

Bell-Magendie Law: States that dorsal roots are sensory, ventral roots are motorâ€”an important exam point. And  **Ventrol**  have motor neurons and Dorsal have sensory neurons.

physio-cns.title: Touch Sensations
physio-cns.paragraph:
| Receptor Type          | Location                                           | Function                                           | Adaptation      |
|------------------------|----------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------|-----------------|
| **Meissnerâ€™s Corpuscles** | Lips, fingertips (hairless skin areas)            | Detect low-frequency vibrations and gentle touch   | Fast-adapting   |
| **Merkel Cells**         | Fingertips, lips (Basal layer of epidermis)       | Sensitive to edges and corners; aid in reading Braille | Slow-adapting   |
| **Pacinian Corpuscles**  | Deep in the skin, interosseous membranes         | Detect deep touch, high-frequency vibrations, and pressure | Fast-adapting   |
| **Ruffini Endings**      | Deep in the skin, ligaments, and tendons         | Sensitive to skin stretch                           | Slow-adapting   |

*Mnemonic: **MMPR** (Meissnerâ€™s, Merkel, Pacinian, Ruffini) â€” useful for exams.*

- A fast adapting refers to detecting changes rather than sustained pressure ie slow adapting.

physio-cns.title: Sensory Processing
physio-cns.paragraph:
## Mechanism
- Receptors convert **mechanical stimuli** (e.g., touch) into **electrical impulses**.

## Fiber Type
- **A-Beta Fibers** carry touch sensation to the CNS.
- Activated by **non-painful stimuli** (e.g., massaging, hot/cold packs, skin rubbing).

## Example
- **Rubbing a painful area** activates A-Beta fibers.

---

# Gate Control Theory

## Concept
- **Non-painful stimuli modulate pain perception** at the spinal cord level.

## Process
1. **A-Beta fibers** are activated by non-painful stimuli (e.g., massage).
2. These fibers stimulate **inhibitory interneurons** in the spinal cord.
3. **Inhibitory interneurons block second-order neurons** carrying pain signals.
4. **Result**: Reduced pain intensity (e.g., rubbing a bruise feels relaxing).

## Significance
- Explains **pain modulation techniques** in clinical practice.

physio-cns.title: Somatosensory pathway
physio-cns.paragraph:
## Ascending Tracts  

The spinal cord carries sensory information to the brain through two major pathways: **Spinothalamic Tracts** (for primitive sensations) and **Dorsal Column Tracts** (for advanced sensations).  

---

##  **Spinothalamic Tracts (Primitive Sensations) â€“ Cross Early** 

Sensory fibers for **crude touch, pressure, pain, and temperature** enter the spinal cord, cross over to the **opposite side** immediately, and ascend to the brain.  

**ðŸ“ Left side damage â†’ Right side sensory loss**  

### **Lateral Spinothalamic Tract (Pain & Temperature)**  
Located on the **outer lateral side** of the spinal cord, this tract transmits **pain and temperature** sensations. If damaged on the left, pain and temperature loss occur on the right side of the body.  

### **Anterior Spinothalamic Tract (Crude Touch & Pressure)**  
Positioned more **anteriorly**, this tract carries **crude touch and pressure** sensations. Just like the lateral tract, it crosses over in the spinal cord, meaning left-side damage affects the right side.  

---

##  **Dorsal Column Tracts (Advanced Sensations) â€“ Cross Late in the Medulla** 

These tracts carry **fine touch, vibration, proprioception, and two-point discrimination**. Unlike the spinothalamic tracts, they **do not cross immediately**. Instead, they travel **on the same side (ipsilateral) within the spinal cord** and only cross over at the **medulla** before reaching the brain.  

**ðŸ“ Left side damage in the spinal cord â†’ Left side sensory loss**  

### **Fasciculus Gracilis (Lower Body Sensations)**  
Located **medially** in the dorsal column, this tract carries **fine touch, vibration, and proprioception from the lower limbs**.  

### **Fasciculus Cuneatus (Upper Body Sensations)**  
Situated **laterally** in the dorsal column, this tract transmits **fine touch and proprioception from the upper body (arms, thorax)**.  

---

## **Key Difference: Early vs. Late Crossings**  
- **Spinothalamic Tracts** cross **immediately in the spinal cord** (opposite-side loss).  
- **Dorsal Column Tracts** stay **on the same side in the spinal cord** and cross **later in the medulla** (same-side loss if damaged in the spinal cord).  

### Sensory Pathway to Cortex

- Sensations travel from the spinal cord â†’ thalamus â†’ cortex.
- Thalamus: Sensory relay center (except olfaction).
- Ventro Posterolateral Nucleus (VPL): Receives all sensations except taste.
- Ventro Posteromedial Nucleus (VPM): Receives taste.
- Motor Nuclei: Ventrolateral, ventromedial, centromedian (motor functions).
- overall path: 1st order neuron(receptor -> spinal cord), 2nd order (spinal -> thalamus) 3rd order (thalamus -> cortex) - > Sensory Pathway to Cortex

physio-cns.title: Pathology Examples
physio-cns.paragraph:
### *Brown-SÃ©quard Syndrome (Hemisection of Spinal Cord)**  
- **Cause:** Damage to one side (hemisection) of the spinal cord.  
- **Effects:**  
  - **Ipsilateral (Same Side) Loss:** Advanced sensations (fine touch, proprioception, vibration) due to dorsal column damage.  
  - **Contralateral (Opposite Side) Loss:** Primitive sensations (pain, temperature) due to spinothalamic tract damage (crosses early).  
- **Example:** A right-sided spinal lesion leads to:  
  - Right-sided loss of **fine touch and proprioception**.  
  - Left-sided loss of **pain and temperature** (below the lesion).  

---

### ðŸ¦  **Tabes Dorsalis (Dorsal Column Degeneration)**  
- **Cause:** Neurosyphilis damages the dorsal columns.  
- **Effect:** Loss of advanced sensations (**fine touch, proprioception**), leading to a **stomping gait** (patients stomp their feet to compensate for the lack of position sense).  

---

### **Syringomyelia (Central Cord Syndrome)**  
- **Cause:** A fluid-filled cavity (syrinx) forms in the central spinal cord, damaging **crossing second-order neurons** that carry primitive sensations.  
- **Effect:**  
  - Loss of **pain, temperature, crude touch, and pressure** (dissociative sensory loss).  
  - **Advanced sensations (fine touch, proprioception) remain intact** because the dorsal columns are unaffected.

physio-cns.title: Near Central Sulcus
physio-cns.paragraph:
We have Gyrus â†‘ Sulcus â†“ Neural tissue. The central sulcus divides the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe
- Primary Motor Cortex **Pre Central Gyrus** (Somatosensory Cortex)
- Somatosensory Cortex **Post Central Gyrus** (All Sensation)
- Brocaâ€™s Area: **Inferior frontal gyrus** (Brodmann 44, 46), motor speech (damage â†’ expressive aphasia, broken speech).
- Wernickeâ€™s Area: **Superior temporal gyrus** (Brodmann 22), comprehension (damage â†’ fluent aphasia, nonsense speech/can't understand).
- Arcuate Fasciculus: Connects Brocaâ€™s and Wernickeâ€™s areas.
- Pleasure Centers: Ventral tegmental area, nucleus accumbens, medial forebrain bundle (addiction-related).
- Vomiting Center: Area postrema (circumventricular organ, outside blood-brain barrier).

physio-cns.title: Sensory Homunculus (cross section of post-central gyrus):
physio-cns.paragraph:
Representation of body parts on the postcentral gyrus:
- Medial Part: Lower body (genitals, legs), blood supplied by anterior cerebral artery (ACA).
- Lateral Part: Upper body (face, hands), blood supplied by the middle cerebral artery (MCA).
- Maximum Representation: Face (especially lips) and hands (especially thumb)â€”large cortical areas due to high receptor density.
- Example: ACA stroke â†’ loss of sensation in contralateral lower limbs; MCA stroke â†’ loss of sensation in contralateral upper body/face.

physio-cns.title: Law of Projection
physio-cns.paragraph:
Concept: Stimulation anywhere in the sensory pathway (receptors, neurons, cortex) â†’ sensation perceived at the receptor level.

- Example: Stimulating cortex with an electrode â†’ patient feels touch on genitals/face, though not physically touched.
- Clinical Relevance: Explains phantom limb phenomenonâ€”amputees feel pain in missing limbs due to cortical irritation or plasticity.

physio-cns.title: Motor Nervous System
physio-cns.paragraph:
We will talk about Descending Tracts.

Cortex -> Spinal Cord

Motor neuron starts from the cortex through the Corticospinal Tracts  
        â†“  
In the lower medulla, **80% of fibers** cross to the **lateral side** 
forming the **Lateral Corticospinal Tract**  
        â†“  
The remaining uncrossed **20% of fibers** forming Anterior Corticospinal Tract then crosses **after the spinal cord**.

### In Depth

Corticospinal Tracts (Pyramidal):

- Origin: Motor cortex (precentral gyrus, Brodmann 4, 6; 60%) + sensory cortex (postcentral gyrus; 40%).
- Pathway: Upper motor neurons (UMNs) descend from the cortex to spinal cord.

Lateral Corticospinal Tract:
- 80% of fibers cross in medulla (pyramidal decussation).
- Travels in lateral spinal cord column.
- Function: Fine motor movements (e.g., writing, painting, needlework) of distal muscles.

Anterior Corticospinal Tract:
- 20% of fibers remain uncrossed, travel in the anterior spinal cord column.
- Cross in the spinal cord before innervating lower motor neurons (LMNs).
-Function: Controls proximal muscles.

physio-cns.title: Some More Tracts In Descending Tracts
physio-cns.paragraph:
### Extrapyramidal Tracts:
- Origin: Brainstem nuclei (midbrain, pons, medulla), not cortex.
- Examples:
- Rubrospinal Tract: From red nucleus, aids fine motor movements with corticospinal tracts.
- Reticulospinal, Tectospinal, Vestibulospinal: Control tone, balance, gross movements.
- Function: Maintain muscle tone, posture, and balance.

### Motor Pathway:
UMNs (Upper Motor Neuron Syndrome)(cortex â†’ spinal cord) regulate LMNs (ventral horn â†’ muscles).
Example: UMN from cortex crosses in medulla, synapses with LMN in spinal cord, causing muscle contraction.

physio-cns.title: Motor Neuron Lesions
physio-cns.paragraph:
### Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) Lesions:
- Analogy: UMNs are parents controlling LMN children.
- Effect: Loss of UMN inhibition â†’ LMNs overfire.
- Symptoms:
- Paralysis (spastic, muscles in spasm).
- Hyperreflexia (exaggerated reflexes).
- Hypertonia (increased muscle tone).
- Positive Babinski sign (toes fan out/upward when sole strokedâ€”normal is flexion).
- Cause: Stroke, spinal cord injury above LMN level.
- Lower Motor Neuron (LMN) Lesions:
### Effect: LMNs dead â†’ no muscle innervation.
- Symptoms:
- Flaccid paralysis (muscles limp).
- Hyporeflexia (reduced reflexes).
- Hypotonia (decreased tone).
- No Babinski sign.
- Cause: Polio, peripheral nerve damage.

physio-cns.title: Muscle Proprioceptors
physio-cns.paragraph:
Extrafusal Fibers: Actin/myosin, contract for movement, innervated by **alpha motor neurons (LMNs)**.

Intrafusal Fibers: Many of these form together, a **muscle spindle(a receptor)** 
 - to detect muscle length, 
- and are innervated by **gamma motor neurons (LMNs)** for contraction + Sensory neurons innervation: Primary 1a fibers and secondary fibers send length information to the CNS.

physio-cns.title: Reflexes : Stretch Reflex (Monosynaptic)
physio-cns.paragraph:
Stimulus: Muscle stretch (e.g., tendon tap with hammer).
- Receptor: Muscle spindle activated.
- Pathway: Primary 1a fibers â†’ synapse(two neuron communicate) directly with alpha motor neuron in spinal cord â†’ muscle contraction.
- Example: Knee-jerk reflex (tap on quadriceps tendon â†’ leg extends).
- Significance: Monosynaptic (one synapse), protects muscle from overstretching.

physio-cns.title: Reflexes : Inverse Stretch Reflex (Disynaptic)
physio-cns.paragraph:
- Stimulus: Excessive tendon tension (e.g., lifting 150 kg weight).
- Receptor: Golgi tendon organ (GTO) in tendon detects tension.
- Pathway: Group 1b fibers **â†’** 1b fiber activate inhibitory interneuron (releases GABA) **â†’** inhibits alpha motor neuron â†’ muscle relaxation.
- Example: Dropping a heavy weight to prevent tendon tear (e.g., biceps rupture in gym).
- Significance: Disynaptic (two synapses) (between 1b and inhibitory interneurons which release GABA **and** GABA inhibits alpha motor neuron) , protective mechanism.

physio-cns.title: Hypothalamus
physio-cns.paragraph: Find a [flowchart](https://www.mermaidchart.com/raw/6c348ad4-3d9b-4b8f-9325-78a029e8dbf9?theme=dark&version=v0.1&format=svg). This will help remember the nucleus.

physio-cns.title: Sleep and EEG
physio-cns.paragraph:
### EEG Waves:
- Alpha (8-12 Hz): Relaxed, eyes closed (Berger waves, inattention waves).
- Beta (13-30 Hz): Active mind (desynchronization waves).
- Gamma (>60 Hz): Intense focus (e.g., problem-solving).
- Theta (4-7 Hz): Light sleep, drowsy (memory waves).
- Delta (1-3 Hz): Deep sleep, dreaming (slow waves).

#### Sleep Phases:
NREM (4 Stages):
- Stage 1: Light sleep (theta waves).
- Stage 2: Sleep spindles, K-complexes (8-12 Hz, longest duration).
- Stages 3-4: Deep sleep (delta waves).
- Parasomnias: Sleepwalking (stages 3-4), bruxism (stage 2), night terrors, bedwetting (not remembered).

### REM:
- Beta waves, PGO spikes (ponto-geniculo-occipital, cause eye movements).
- Paradoxical sleep (sleeping but active brain).
- Muscles relaxed (except diaphragm, extraocular muscles).
- Nightmares (bad dreams, remembered).

physio-cns.title: PYQ
physio-cns.paragraph:
Stretch Reflex Mediator: Muscle spindles.

Medial Lemniscus Lesion (Pons): Loss of tactile/proprioception on opposite side.

Inferior Frontal Gyrus Injury: Motor speech area (Brocaâ€™s) affected.

Cervical Spine Injury (Lateral Dorsal Column): Ipsilateral arm proprioception loss.

Multiple Sclerosis: Oligodendrocytes (demyelination).

Brown-SÃ©quard Syndrome: Pain/temperature loss on opposite side.

Reward Center: Ventral tegmental area.

Subthalamic Nucleus Lesion: Hemiballismus.

Least Conduction Velocity: C fibers (postganglionic autonomic, slow pain, warm temperature).

Pressure on Arm (Sleeping): A-alpha fibers affected first â†’ weakness, no numbness.
